Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Stepwise Functionalization and Surface Modification for ZnO Nanostructure-based Biosensors

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1264508(Lu) The goal of the proposed research is to perform in-depth scientific understanding of surface and interface chemistry of nanostructured ZnO and MgZnO and biomolecules in order to design and develop the innovative surface functionalization at the molecular level to enable a new generation of biosensors with ultra-high sensitivity and selectivity, and multi-modal operation. This multidisciplinary research will include MOCVD growth of ZnO and MgZnO nanostructures with controlled dimension and morphology, design and experiments of chemical binding of molecular linker layers, comprehensive characterization of the ZnO/organic molecule interfaces, and implementation of the functionalization technology for sensing applications. The main approach includes (i) synthesis of highly ordered ZnO and MgZnO nanostructures with controlled dimension, morphologies, and surface wettability; (ii) Study of the photophysical and chemical properties between these nanostructures and the molecular linker layers designed by using the probe chromophores to achieve unprecedented understanding of the interfacial chemistry, and (iii) Implementation of the interfacial chemistry to design and develop the surface functionalization technology for application in the ZnO nanostructure-based biosensors.

General public statement:
This project will study how molecules important in sensor development, for example antibodies or enzymes, may be immobilized on nanomaterials. Ensuring that biomolecules function well after immobilization is critical to the successful development of biosensors and this proposal will develop new immobilization strategies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the proposed multidisciplinary research was to perform in-depth scientific understanding of surface and interface chemistry of nanostructured zinc oxide (ZnO) and magnesium zinc oxide (MZO) and biomolecules to develop innovative surface functionalization at the molecular level of these materials. The ultimate goal is that this knowledge will enable a new generation of biosensors with ultra-high sensitivity and selectivity and multi-modal operation. 

The main approach includes (i) systematic synthesis of highly ordered ZnO and MZO nanostructures with controlled dimension, morphologies, and surface wettability; (ii) design and experiment of chemical binding of molecular linker layers, comprehensive characterization of the ZnO/organic molecule interfaces, (iii) study of the photophysical and chemical properties of molecular linker layers carrying especially designed tags and bound to ZnO and MZO to achieve unprecedented understanding of the interfacial chemistry, and (iv) implementation of stepwise interfacial reactions to develop the surface functionalization technologies that are necessary for  the ZnO nanostructure-based biosensors.  

Project Outcomes Based on Intellectual Merit:  Nanostructured ZnO materials are important in materials chemistry due to their unique properties, resulting from the combination of a large surface area and multifunctionality. Up to now, most research has focused on growth methods of ZnO nanostructures with tuned physical properties, and fabrication of optoelectronic devices. However, considerably less information on the interfaces between nanostructured ZnO and organic molecules is available, because of the complexity and difficulty of the chemical functionalization. One example is instability of ZnO to most acids and bases. Our research through this grant enabled a solution to this problem and accomplished an optimized synthesis of highly ordered MZO nanostructures with tailored magnesium (Mg) composition, controlled dimension, finely tuned surface morphologies, and low toxic Zinc ion content. We also achieved binding uniformity and efficiency of the surface bound molecular layer and  studied in depth the mechanism  of interfacial chemistry behavior for the surface functionalization of ZnO and MZO. This was accomplished through infrared techniques that allowed imaging of the binding process. This process also included azide-to-folic acid surface click reactiona with various concentrations and reaction times for sensor sensitivity studies. The resistance of the functionalized ZnO and MZO film to etching were evaluated. We also fabricated MZO-based sensor devices, especially the MZO thin film transistor (TFT), a microelectronic device whose active sensing area are designed and modified for biochemical binding studies. The groups demonstrated biosensing ability of the fabricated devices and evaluated the quality of the sensor material as well as the linkage chemistry.  During the grant period the PIs as well as their students disseminated the research results and achievements through articles in peer-reviewed journals,  and presentations in international conferences. Both PIs presented this work at lectures in various universities and invited talks at international conferences.

 

       Project Outcomes Based on Broader Impact: This multidisciplinary and collaborative research project coherently combined fundamental chemistry, material science, and electrical engineering. It encompassed nanomaterial synthesis, comprehensive characterizations, surface chemistry, and sensors development, which broadened the scientific education and training of students from both laboratories, enhancing their professional outlook. Student exchange from the USAID program and co-advising of Ph.D. theses have regularly taken place and are still ongoing. Four Ph.D. students received extensive training, two of whom already received their degrees and are gainfully employed in Intel and Advanced Materials. Five Capstone Senior Design Projects were done in the ZnO nano-biosensor areas under the PI’s supervision done for this grant's research. Two undergraduate Slade Honor Scholars were mentored on their undergraduate research projects that are part of the research undertaken in this grant. The outreach efforts were mainly directed at NJ high school students, including Newark High schools. The project  involved  women in  chemistry and engineering research and undergraduate students from various universities. The PI's group participated in The Academy at Rutgers for Girls in Engineering and Technology (TARGET) program where two high school female students were mentored in the microelectronic device fabrication project and a public presentation. Two female undergraduate students from Florida State University and Northwestern University completed a summer research internship under the PIs supervision. The PIs also enabled the training through this grant of five high school students at the NJ Governor’s School for Science, Engineering and Technology (GSET) program, and the Science Bus program.
